abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Aviation Project for
            India was approved by the IDA on October 20, 1970, and
            became effective on May 25, 1971. Since effectiveness there
            had been slow progress in implementation, from the setting
            up of training centers to the prequalification for the
            purchase of aircrafts. The Borrower made satisfactory
            progress in preparation for the commencement of lending
            operations for private operators. Two supervision missions
            in May and October 1971 reported that difficulties were
            encountered in getting the training program underway due to
            administrative delays and cumbersome bureaucratic
            procedures. The report implies that, since a lack of
            domestic commitment to the project was obvious from the
            beginning, there were substantial shortcomings in Bank
            performance. In February 1971, the Government informed the
            Bank that as a result of the war on the sub-continent, a
            general directive to re-examine foreign exchange priorities
            had been issued. The use of foreign exchange for crop
            spraying was questioned. In June 1972, the Government also
            proposed in alterations to the project to permit
            indigenously produced aircraft to compete in procurement.
            The Bank rejected this proposal and the Government did not
            agree to revert to the original specifications until June
            1973. In September 1973, the Government requested to
            transfer the training program from the Department of
            Agriculture to the Directorate of Civil Aviation. The Bank
            agreed, but wanted to see the details of the proposal.
            Another supervision mission in December 1973 was still
            unable to obtain documentation of progress. Finally, on June
            21, 1974, the Government informed the Bank that its
            priorities had changed and requested cancellation of the
            credit. The Board cancelled the loan on August 13, 1974. The
            loan was never disbursed and is, therefore, not rated.
